text: As you read, focus on how a backdoor adjustment set removes confounding. Identify which variables block noncausal backdoor paths and why descendants of the treatment must be avoided.
Identify the core claim about a backdoor set and the assumptions it requires. Ask whether any variable is a missed confounder, a forbidden descendant, or a collider that could invalidate the set.
Connect the idea of blocking backdoor paths to your existing understanding of confounding and statistical control. Think about how conditioning on the right variables removes spurious associations.
Summarize what a backdoor adjustment set is, why it identifies causal effects, and how it works graphically. Explain the idea in your own words, as if teaching it.
Compare backdoor adjustment to related methods such as front-door adjustment or instrumental variables. Focus on how each method handles confounding and identifies causal effects.
Focus on why a valid backdoor set cannot include descendants of the treatment. Including such variables introduces post-treatment bias and distorts the causal effect.
Focus on identifying colliders and understanding why conditioning on them opens spurious associations. A valid backdoor set blocks confounders but must avoid colliders.
Consider why a near-miss adjustment set fails. Identify whether the problem is a missing confounder, a forbidden descendant, or a collider that breaks backdoor validity or minimality.
